data: Fragments of a monumental Greek inscription
Two non-joining fragments of a thick slab or panel of local limestone.
The letters have a plain, regular deep cut form without serifs. Alpha has broken bar; beta has small, closed and separated eyes; omicron is full size; omega is rhomboid and closed

Probably to be associated with one of the construction phases of the theatre (initial construction end of the 4th century BCE; second phase c. 200 BCE, third phase initiated c. 100 BCE, following Isler), but the letter forms make a date before the second century BCE highly unlikely

A two-floor structure, with the public buildings displayed on the ground floor (theatre, temple of Aphrodite, bouleuterion) and the private buildings on the upper floor (archaic house c.500 BC), hellenistic houses, Roman house. Excellent displays of ceramics, tiles, small finds, architectural pieces. Many terracotta inscriptions, and 2 Greek stone inscriptions + 2 Arabic ones
Contrada Perciana San Cipirello - Monreale (PA) At start of road up to archaeological site of Monte Iato
Hans Peter Isler, ‘Grabungen auf dem Monte Iato 1997’, Antike Kunst 41, no. 1 (1998): 40–50
Monte Iato: la ventisettesima campagna di scavo
Hans Peter Isler, «Monte Iato: la ventisettesima campagna di scavo», Sicilia Archeologica 30, fasc. 93–95 (1997): 23–44
Hans Peter Isler, ‘Grabungen auf dem Monte Iato 1986’, Antike Kunst 30, no. 1 (1987): 25–33
Monte Iato: la sedicesima campagna di scavo
Hans Peter Isler, «Monte Iato: la sedicesima campagna di scavo», Sicilia Archeologica 19, fasc. 62 (1986): 29–48
Hans Peter Isler, «Monte Iato: scavi 1995-1997», in Terze Giornate Internazionali di Studi sull’area elima, vol. 2, 2 voll. (Pisa: Scuola Normal Superiore di Pisa, 2000), 715–29

Apparatus criticus

  • Texts based upon Isler, SEG and comparison with photographs;
  • #frB.1: Isler: ΡΑΒΩ
  • #frB.2: Isler: ΧΙΑΙ

translation

commentary

Isler suggests reading Antallos in line 1. It is very plausible that IGPalermo 40 = ISic001560, found at Monte Iato in 1969, constitutes part of the same inscription (Isler 2000 argues for the association), but without autopsy of the piece and proper comparison with these two fragments we continue to treat it as a distinct fragment for now.

limestone plaque chiselled

The letters have a plain, regular deep cut form without serifs. Alpha has broken bar; beta has small, closed and separated eyes; omicron is full size; omega is rhomboid and closed

Line 1-3 110 Interlineation line 1 to 2 Ietas Monte Iato 37.967050, 13.198199 Probably to be associated with one of the construction phases of the theatre (initial construction end of the 4th century BCE; second phase c. 200 BCE, third phase initiated c. 100 BCE, following Isler), but the letter forms make a date before the second century BCE highly unlikely I.5A

Damaged upper left and upper right, parts of the lower left side, the whole of the lower edge, and a small part of the upper edge are preserved, while the block is broken on the right side.

44 60 18

Three lines of monumental letters, of which the beginnings of lines 2 and 3 are preserved

Fragment is broken on both sides and on the lower edge, but intact above

29
